conbody.p: When all components are deployed and you have verified operation of the application is managing and basic cluster failover in a controlled scenario, you are ready to configure and enable fencing in your production environment. Fencing is an automated means of isolating a node that appears to be malfunctioning to protect the integrity of the DRBD volume(s).

We recommend placing the fencing device on the public network. The reason for placing the fencing device on the public network is explained by how fencing and communication work in various implementations. In this case the two implementations are a public versus a private network interface for fencing communications.
conbody.note: If you do not define a fencing method, your failover will fail with an error no method defined when the cluster attempts to fail over to the backup node.
